number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Although I am usually NOT a fan of Roguelike perma-death / Start over type games (& over, and over, and over, etc), Long Live the Queen is too perfectly charming not to like.It is a very well designed game. You learn as you go, how to avoid certain traps by focusing on learning certain skills before others. It took me a few short-lived (for the Queen) run-thrus to get the hang of the simple system. Or rather, to see what choices I should have made early on. But really, you're going to be doing that throughout the game anyway.It's not as easy as I thought it would be. But you start caring about the little Queen and you really want her to succeed....or live for that matter. And keeping her alive is no easy task. At least not for me. The dialog options are good & you make choices that really matter & that have potentially severe consequences. IMO the writing is very tight in this area. It's one of the things I liked most. It has slight RPG elements, in that you decide what she will learn. The classes you choose for her will increase her skill in specific areas, all of which are vitally important to her continued existence, and all of which will affect your dialog options at some point throughout the entire game. It's all tied together very nicely.So if you are a fan of games with a decent story, or a fan of Roguelikes in general, I recommend you buy this little gem and enjoy the heck out of it. If you like Visual Novels you will enjoy this....though Queen is a LOT more interactive than most VN's as it is an actual game first.It's a fun little game to spend time with & I certainly encourage everyone to try it!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Long Live The Queen is a game that features trial and error, logical thinking and strategy. To win, Elodie must survive to her coronation, but there are a lot of dangers on the way. Every week, you can pick two classes to let Elodie study on, varying from social skills to combat experience. An important factor is Elodie's mood: It's hard to be social when you're depressed, but that's a good opportunity to learn more about something cheerful, like singing. Each weekend you can let Elodie do an activity that affects her mood (while the story may also affect it a little, such as a snake scaring Elodie). When skilled enough in a certain area, such as for example Military, Elodie can unlock a Military outfit that boosts said skill a little.As stated, strategy will be involved as Elodie's skills heavily affects how the story plays out. For example, there is a part where Elodie is given a box of chocolate that is poisoned. Depending on certain skills, Elodie will either know it is poisoned, or she will have the patience to leave it for later (in which a steward steals it, leading to his death). Lacking any of these, means you aren't even given the option to not eat the chocolate as Elodie will be too eager to feel the sweet taste of soon-to-be-death.This is why it is also a bunch of trial-and-error: Your first time playing, you're not going to know what's coming at you; eventually you'll slowly progress and remember what events are coming ahead in which you can plan stratetic mood alterings to help you level up the skills needed to pass the events.It's a very calm and fun game that I can recommend to people who want something really simple.Not recommended for the faint of heart who can't read about Elodie dying in many different ways...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Long Live The Queen is a simulation role-playing-game that places you in the role of a princess on the road to becoming queen. Placing aside the images usually conjured by well-known fairy tales, being a princess as it turns out is very difficult. To make it to your coronation you will need to better yourself and make important decisions along the way. There is a lot to learn as a princess, everything from etiquette to history to military strategy to athletics and everything in between. Careful selection of what you learn and how well you learn it can open up new opportunities as well as avoid nasty failures on skill checks. How well you learn a subject is also dependent on your mood which can shift depending on what actions you take and how you spend your weekends.In many ways, Long Live The Queen is similar to Princess Maker which also features a princess with different skills to learn. The key difference being that in Princess Maker you play a king raising a daughter where as Long Live The Queen places you in the role of the princess dealing with political issues of every sort. There is a lot of agency to Long Live The Queen and the story can take radically different turns depending on what actions you take and how well versed you are in certain subjects. So there is much more at stake in Long Live The Queen than in Princess Maker. Who do you trust? Do you take the diplomatic solution or use force? Do you get involved in problems where success is not guaranteed? The first few times playing you will usually meet an untimely demise before ever seeing your coronation.Overall, Long Live The Queen is a fantastic and refreshing game. With so many decisions to make, there are a number of directions the story can go. And even if you fail, it's still enjoyable to just get back up and try again with something different. So if you've ever wanted to be a princess or just have fun as a ruler, I would highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												I have played this game for a little over an hour and a half, and thus far I have been:shot by an arrow (twice),poisoned, andstabbed by an angry noble in a duel.This game is addicting in the way Choose Your Own Adventure books are addicting; when you make the wrong choice, you want to go back and try again. Unfortunately, unlike those books you can't necessarily just go back to the last choice you made and start over; some events are the result of choices you made much eariler in the game. (Hint: frequent saves on multiple save files are your very, very best friend.) This game also benefits from the reasonably engaging story line (drama and intrigue galore; shades of Game of Thrones), stats system based on education (appealing to my dorkiest tendencies), and general adorableness even when your princess is skewered on somebody's rapier. It's a bit like a visual novel and RPG meshed in an oddly endearing way. I'm a little frustrated with my inability to progress beyond a certain point, but that's my fault for not saving more often!TL;DR: Fun for OCD nihilists everywhere!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												This is only what I thought of the gme you can skip to the pros and cons at the bottom if you'd like.Opinion: How do you know a game is good? When even though it angers and infuriates you, you still keep coming back for more and that's exactly what this game does. As of yet I have died many times from various things that seem innocent at the time but killed me later and every time I only get more furious with the game, for example please tell me how a Decoration skill matters in a magical duel to the death? But it's also for this reason that the game is so good, there are so many interlocking events that you will find yourself eager to replay it again and again with each time trying a new method to see how far it gets you. To put it in perspective there are so many skills and events that the game's wiki couldn't make a walkthrough of it. This game will make you embrace your inner paranoia and I loved it.Pros:Extreme replayabilityEvery action has a consequenceDifferent and interactive storylinesTreats player as intelligentThrows the player right into the gameExtremely good funCons:Soundtrack could have flowed better with the gameOutfits for the character were kind of annoyingSome of the deaths and skills were frustrating (the Decoration example to name one)Confusingly large number of characters.Never explains what mood affects each skillSteep learning curveFinal verdict: Worth a buy  8/10Long Live The Queen!

												well... crap.I remember a very old game for the late DOS era called Princess Maker. I saw this and knew it was an obvious reimagining of the same idea. I never really played visual novels before, but after two hours into this experience I was enthralled. So simple, so stupid, there's no reason I should have enjoyed it as much as I did. Limited ability to fill your wide assortment skill sheets adds for some incredibly demanding replay value as you'll wanna keep seeing what happens differently. If you're a fan of anime drama and comedy like I am, you'll probably love this. If this isn't your flavor, by no means will it change your mind, but it's a ton of fun and a great way to relax. Heavy action games are great, playing online with friends is great, but here it's all about interesting decision making. It's silly and cute to fault and some of the writing is just plain duimb, but that's the charm of it. it's a surprisingly entertaining experience and an easy recommendation for people who like anime comdies and or old PC adventure games. ...long live this game

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												As a girl, I'm supposed to like these kind of games. Well, I've got something to tell you: this is no child's play.You have no idea how many people would like to see a 14-years-old pink-haired soon-to-be-queen princess dead.It's almost impossible to win on your first gameplay. You have to deal with Elodie's emotions very well. You also have know which skills you want to train beforehand so you can manipulate her feelings and earn bonus.I don't usually play visual novels, but this one is special. While it doesn't have any dark secret to be found at the end of the story, it sure can surprise you. It's quite difficult to predict what's going to happen next, even after some playthroughs.It's -not- a date simulator, and there's little to no romance in this game - of course you'll marry someone eventually, butthat's not important.The best part is that you can actually create your own personality for Elodie in each gameplay. There are a lot of options that cover almost every type of person you want her to be. I recommend you to have a couple of saves of the same gameplay, but some weeks apart. You never know when you're going to get busted out of nowhere.But mostly I recommend this game. If you bought it with the Humble Bundle and still did not give it a try, you should.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												A cross between interactive story and Princess Maker, this game puts you in charge of Princess Elodie. She is a 13 year old girl who's mother, the Queen, has just died and she now has a year to prepare for her coronation and rulership, as she'll take the throne at age 14. You decide what classes she takes each week, as she'll need certain skills to progress the story in certain ways. Maybe she'll know enough about Espionage to realize nobles are plotting against her? Or what if she doesn't know enough about Court Manners to know that necklace from a distance noble is a courting gift? Will she be able to survive an assassination attempt?With multiple different endings, fans of the Princess Maker series and interactive stories will definitely love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												An excellent little game that never fails to entertain. I've spent longer playing this than I predicted at first. Although it looks simple at first, the game requires a significant amount of planning - especially for some of the crazier endings and even to beat the game the first time. The number of ways to die is impressive and I have stumbled into more of them that I could ever want. I’d buy it again in a heartbeat.Pros:The game play is simple and has a low learning curve - but beating the game is hard. The graphics are clean and the writing has more than one laugh-out-loud moment. There are a ton of different ways to play a run through and if you're willing to die (A LOT) you can see them all.Music was lovely.Cons:How the mood effects the skills is hard to figure out at many times.It's relatively easy to miss a lot of the content – even through different playthroughs – unless you are super obsessive about logging/recording each game.Anything I’d change?:I'd really have liked a log book that detailed the characters and their backgrounds and secrets as you learned them through various play throughs. A lot of the skills added to the lore of the world but you could only see them on the skill increase screen in game. A missed opportunity.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Long Live the Queen is an odd title, but very in its own niche. If you can get passed the "anime" aesthetic (which is more "moe" than anything else), you find yourself in a heavily political fantasy game. Every class you take to build your skill tree is important to your survival as well as the relationships you build in your own kingdom and on. What may seem daunting and a little frustrating at first, you'll come to find that some deaths are avoidable, even without having the proper skills (such as choosing not to follow the shady figure in the woods). Events are also not random, so the more you play, the lower the difficulty gauge. Overall, I find this little gemstone to be alright for what it is. It's not a horrible time-waster, and it's pleasing enough on the eye. However I would reccommend only getting this game while it's on sale ($5 or less), as it's short and does not have as much replay value as one would hope.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Do you have what it takes to stay alive? Probably not. Will it tick you off to no end?Probably. Will it be fun? Only if you're masochistic. As it turns out, I am apparently masochistic. This game is extremely addictive, with a relatively simple yet alarmingly improbable premise: survive to your fifteenth birthday. You'll face traitorous relatives, violent monsters, unpredictable magic, court room drama, espionage, and murder. There are more ways to die in this game than to survive. You'll get at least four hours play out of it just trying to survive one playthrough. It's the kind of game that will make you try and try again, and the various outcomes and differences in decision can drastically alter the storyline. Ergo, while certain events over the course of playthrough will stay the same, the end result of differing choices will likely be new to you long into becoming familiar with the game. All in all, Long Live The Queen is a fun (annoying) little game that will provide hours of entertainment (frustration). It has great art, a quirky storyline, and is perfect for visual novel fans. 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												I got the game in a bundle without even knowing what it was, and I'm so glad that I did. I'm a meticulous person at heart, and organization is a personal passion. So when I started this game, with branching paths all over the place and all different unlockable story components and opportunities, I was in heaven. I've got a Word document saved right now, detailing the different paths and the effects of succeeding or failing each test. It's far from complete, and I'm certain there will be hours and hours of additional entertainment as I seek out the deaths, epilogues, and achievements that still elude me as I fill in more of my ever-growing chart of options.Be aware, there's no such thing as a "perfect" game. I nearly drove myself mad attempting to raise stats in such a way that I passed every test. You simply cannot, and I think it's for the better. The game forces you to choose what knowledge and opportunities are most important to you and give up the rest or simply save it for another playthrough.The artwork and different outfits are cute, and I appreciated that aspect of the game. However, if you do buy the game (and if you're anything like me, I hope you do because you'll have a blast), make sure you're doing it for the strategy and story element, since those are what truly make the game something special.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												This game has the best frustration-balance I ever encountered in a game. Build up to counter the death you just experienced, just to die even earlier this time because you did not train something you did on last try. It's possible to beat it without a guide, but you need either an extreme amount of luck, or very many playthroughs to get it right, and as someone who build myself up through a high number of playthroughs, I don't think I've ever been so satisfied with beating a game before. And by beating I mean not dying. You play princess Elodie on her last weeks before being crowned a queen after the tragic death of her mother. Your goal is to survive until then. Apparently you're safe forever if you're a queen, even though you can die from absolutely anything before then. You build up her day by taking her to lessons.  You earn outfits that give bonuses to some stats. Your mood gives bonuses and disadvantages for learning certain lessons and doing a sparetime activity in the castle changes Elodie's mood. You can be a master tactician of every type or war and then die from poisoned chocolate. Having 0 knowledge actually mean 0 knowledge for Elodie and she does the dumbest things if she gets in a situation she knows nothing about. Creates a lot of humour in the game.If you want every achievement you absolutely must use a guide to get the right skills at the right times, through many playthroughs. The game is more enjoyable if you play it to be crowned through knowledge you earn through many tries.The game seems complicated at first try, but you easily get into it and learn to juggle skills, moods, classes, and, of course, dresses. I recommend it, but be prepared for frustration, though you'll pull through because of the humour of the absurd deaths and the cutesyness of the game and music.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												tl;dr If you like this kind of game (pick-your-own, number crunch-y, visual novel and kind of dating sim-like), it's a very nice example of what it is. Otherwise, you're probably not going to like it. Initially,I sucked at the game and hated it. Then, I used a couple of walkthroughs, lightbulb moment happened and now I quite like it. It's a text-based game with consequences, but it's not as straightforward as that.  If you're slightly mathsy: instead of 'do x and y will happen' it sometimes feels more like x + v + u * w means y is very likely to happen, and maybe z too if your character feels more depressed that day'. It makes it almost realistic. In a way. It's still not going to appeal to everyone, though. My pros:- Outcome engine well designed, and well-disguised, which prevents the game from feeling simplistic despite first appearances. - Art is cute. Music doesn't irritate me despite the repetitiveness.- The dating sim element is more interesting than most and doesn't feel tacky or forced. Except for the bit where she can get forced into marriage, of course, but I'm talking about gameplay here.- This is basically a quick hit if you like achievement mining. I like achievement mining. My cons:- It's a visual novel-style game. For many players unfamiliar with them, or maybe text-based RPG games, I think it's not going to feel that engaging. Having to scrutinise a balance sheet of skills every round might not be that appealing to some either. - Wasn't the most intuitive game for me - had to rely on walkthroughs until I actually understood how to not keep dying by week 20. But that's probably my fault. - In terms of replayability, it can get very repetitive after a while. But I'm on something like my 35th playthrough.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2013
												A fun, and often frustrating, "visual novel"-like game, Long Live the Queen puts you in the shoes of a fourteen year old, the heir to the throne, and has you build your character based on the skills you learn each in-game week. Be wary, however, as the game has multiple game-over scenarios, in which an assassin may strike you down, or even a civil war might break out. An excellent choice for those who want to experience a different kind of game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												Long Live the Queen was not quite the game I expected, in spite of the fact that it's everything it promised to be on the cover. In this royalty simulator, you control Elodie, a precocious little pink-haired 14-year-old princess who, upon her mother's death, has been thrust into the role of matriarch. Establishing this game firmly in the G.R.R. Martin school of political thought, your goal is not so much to save the world from evil or to rule as a beloved queen should, but to survive long enough to reach your coronation.Your country is weak, your neighbors ambitious, and your education incredibly limited; spend your time training up the many, many skills you'll need to be an effective leader, juggling pressing needs for the kingdom with personal desires to help you get what you want. Meanwhile, the constant flood of events around you will send your emotions scattering all over, and since it's hard to study Military Strategy when you're terrified or Court Manners when you're feeling defiant, you must manage your personal time to keep you in the right state of mind. On top of all that, you'll be asked time and again to commit money or military strength to a number of causes; until you've trained up the proper understanding of economics and military theory, you won't even be aware these resources exist, let alone that they're something you should be mindful of. Screw up along the way and you're dead - assassins, poisoned gifts, bandits, monsters... There are plenty of horrible things out to get you. And they will. Repeatedly. It's a surprisingly anxiety-ridden pile of disasters to manage, and while I adore it, your mileage may vary.On top of that, there's also a decent story set behind everything, though your point of view limits what you can see. The cast of characters is overwhelming at first, but you quickly start to remember which ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s backstabbed you and which actually seem to be decent enough human beings. There are plenty of story paths to follow, plenty of branches that reveal details otherwise hidden, and plenty of endings to grab. Are you a meek and pretty trophy wife? A blood-stained military empress? A strange and terrifying witch-queen? Bear the demands of the throne, squeeze what you want out of the spare time you are given, and you can forge whatever destiny you so choose.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												If you are looking for an action-y, fast pace, adventure; turn the other way. However, if you are looking for a game with endless hours of replayability, some absolutly hilarious dialouge, a visual novel-esque story, and micromanaging, then you have come to the right place!I would honestly rate this game as one of the best I've ever played. You play as Elodie, a princess who is not yet old enough for the crown, but needs to prepare for when she is old enough. You must micromanage all of her skills in order to bring her to survive all of the horrors of being in charge.It may seem a bit overwhelming at first, failing checks left and right. But, that is the fun of it, if you die early, you know what you must prepare for in the next playthrough. Do not fret though, as you get each skill up to a higher level, you gain special outfits in order to help boost certain fields in order to let you focus on others that you may have neglected.The game is witty, fun, challenging, and always pulls you in for more.tl;dr: 10/10 would buy three times over

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												This is not your average visual novel. You are in charge and you make every decision. And there are a LOT of decisions. You will die in many more ways than you'll ever win.In Long Live the Queen, you guide Princess Elodie on her journey to becoming the Queen of Nova, an empire that has lost a lot of its old strength. It's up to you to prepare yourself for your coronation in 40 weeks on your 15th birthday. There are many obstacles in your path such as warring neighbors, magical secrets, and flirty princes. How you establish yourself as the Queen is entirely up to you.The game is played one week at a time allowing you to train Elodie in two skills from a list of about forty and usually followed by an event in the evening that forces you to make a game changing decision. Making these decisions is difficult due to the cost and reward trade-offs that are not always visible. Your available options during events as well as the outcome of your choices are determined by skill checks that show if you've failed, succeeded, or partially succeeded. It's impossible to play a perfect game as you cannot train your skills to pass each event. This gives the game an ample amount of replay value to go back and train different skills to pass different events.Training skills is more complicated than simply picking a class to learn. There are bonuses and penalties applied to learning skill groups based on your current most overwhelming mood. Throughout the game you will encounter events that make you angry, afraid, cheerful, depressed, willful, yielding, pressured, and/or lonely and it's a difficult balancing act to push Elodie into the mood that fits your current strategy. At the end of each week you also get the opportunity to do a simple activity that gives you some control over which mood Elodie will be in during the following week. Mastering control of Elodie's mood is extremely important and learning the mechanics behind it is vital to your success.The setting, story, and mood all play very well together in Long Live the Queen. The developer clearly had a strong idea of what stories were to be presented and, although it might not look like it at first, everything has an importance. The music can be a little repetitive, but it does change frequently enough between classes, events, and activities that I never grew tired of it. I was often aware of where the game was headed based on music cues and facial expressions of the characters without having to read any of the text. The dialog never drags on, but if you've viewed the scene before you have the option to skip the text which I never used until I had completed the majority of the game.I love this game. My girlfriend loves this game. My girlfriends loves the fact that I love this game. I expect many men to never give this game a chance simply because it's a game about being a princess and they are truly missing a great game. If you have ever enjoyed a choose-your-own-adventure book/game then I would highly suggest you buy this game and play it right now. Starting is easy, learning is tough. You'll die in the first 30 minutes of the game unless you're very careful or very lucky. Even dying is entertaining though. Overcoming those events that were a hard roadblock for you feels like a huge accomplishment. I felt as if I had beat the game on a few occasions before I ever reached the end. And when I reached the end, I immediately started over with a plan to pass that event on week 30. It was well worth it.Play this game if you're not afraid of being poisoned, ambushed, overthrown, blasted by magic into dust, or eaten by a giant sea monster. Also, the old forest is not safe. DO NOT GO INTO THE OLD FOREST!

Posted: December 28, 2013
												I don't feel this game is going to be for everyone, but I've enjoyed my time in it so far.  The world is fairly interesting to find out about and I've enjoyed trying to predict the skills I'm going to need.  It's definately a game that only has a limited amount of interesting gameplay, due to the fact that the story / events are very linear.  That said, it appears to have a lot of branching elements to it, which should give enough content to make it interesting for a while at least.The art is something you are either going to hate or love... I for one enjoy the overal 'cute' factor of the art when it is coupled with a lot of the sometimes very dark themes happening in the game.I will say that it feels like it's going to be awhile and a challenge to actually get Princess Elodie to make it to her coronation alive though.Ultimately, if you find the entire concept of a japanese style visual novel boring, this game won't change that opinion at all.  However, if you have even a slight interest or curiosity about the genre, this could be a pretty fun look in to that world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Misconceptions:  First off, Long Live the Queen is NOT a Medieval Dating system.  While you may have the rare opportunity to marry for political reasons, the resulting rammifications of such an action is the key point.  No drawn out romance here.  This is a game driven by politics with a focus on the feelings of our protganist, as she is thrust into unfamilar territory.Summary:  LLTQ takes you through 40 weeks of young Princess Elodie's life with the ultimate goal of...survival.  You see, Elodie has a penchant for dying.  Make the right skill checks at the right time and she'll make it through.  In a rough situation, you might even survive by making only one of several skill checks.  Just remember.  Being the perfect military strategist won't save you from being stabbed in the face, and even for a princess, climbing just might be a useful talent.Ultmately, Elodie is yours to shape.  You can train two skills each week with four "mood" sliders which dictate any bonuses (or penalties) her training will provide.  If her mood is currently "willful," she'll have an easy time with military training...but any skill under Royal Demeanor will take heavy penalities.  There can be many sides to Elodie.  Experiment and see which mood(s) will bring about the greatest skill bonuses.  I would say skill bonuses in training are tantamount to building a well-rounded princess.Cons:-This is "scripted" to a degree.  For most events, if it happens in Week 9 once...it happens in Week 9 every time.-There will be a little trial and error.  Expect to hit an event in which you've trained none of the requisite skills to survive.Pros:-A "scripted" event can play out very differently each time, depending on skills trained or the choice picked.-Variety.  Elodie can end up as a crazed Totalitarian or a champion of the people, and everything in between.-Death and avoiding it.  Dying is fun sometimes.  Other times, three or four *seemingly* random skills might each have a chance to keep you breathing.-Multiple playthroughs.  I've beaten this perhaps five times.  I feel as if there's plenty more to learn of the world.-Character.  There's something unique about LLTQ.  Pleasantly devious with a slight cute edge.  Sure, that sums it up.Final Thoughts:  Honestly, my brain is a bit foggy as I haven't played Long Live the Queen in maybe two weeks.  I don't feel as if I've given the title all the praise it deserves, nor do I currently have the words to do so.If you like Simulation-lite games, buy this.  If you like more strategy in your Simulations, buy this and aim for the tougher challenges and endings.  If you prefer RPGs...well, just buy it already.  (8.5/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												This game's a lot of fun, though it does bear some explanation of what, exactly, you're getting into.This is basically a choose-your-own adventure story wherein a young, cutsey-looking anime princess must navigate a brutal, Game of Thrones-esque year of political intrigue and repeated assassination attempts/invasions via building skills and the occasional dialog option.  There are multiple endings, though the vast majority are the ones where she dies in some awful, often unexpected way.  Unless you max out your omen-reading skill.  Then you'll sometimes see 'em coming.Any-hoo, the game's surprisingly mature.  I don't mean there's a lot of nudity or whatever, simply that it handles rather gritty subject matter in a rather circumspect and mature way.  The plot branches about depending on skill choices and the like, so there's a surprising amount of replay value involved.  If you enjoy political intrigue or find the idea of a grim and gritty world conveyed through cutesy anime visuals, you'll probably get a few hours of enjoyment out of this one.Or die trying, I suppose.I give it Several out of A Number That Is Slightly Higher Than Several.  4.73 out of 5.223~, maybe.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I haven't played tons of VNs, but I've enjoyed the few I have played, and so it's nice to see some leaking into major English markets like Steam. The biggest issues with getting quality VNs put up is that most of them are Eroge (which is to say adult only) games, followed with the issue that the VN genre is rather wide, ranging from literally a book you make minor decisions in, to lots of gameplay coupled with long visual still scenes and text. LLTQ pulls off a nice balace of gameplay and story text, with a fun pace that won't bore you. This makes it a great entry level game of you are new to the VN genre and want to see what it can offer.LLTQ is not very long for the price tag, and the art isn't anything amazing (in fact it comes off as rather generic). However, LLTQ makes up for this with interesting gameplay and plenty of replayability. Half the fun of this game is taking different paths and trying new things to see how it ends up for Princess Elodie, and the game pulls this off with a lot of grace. While not a strict VN, the game doesn't have much action. If you're looking for something akin to Kamidori or Sengoku Rance, you're barking up the wrong tree. However, if you enjoy VNs in general and like some quirky and strategy based gameplay tossed in, LLTQ should make you a happy camper.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This game is very involved, and as simple as it seems, you could die at any time.CONS:1) It's very easy to fail "tests" as you really don't know what you need to study and what you can ignore. And then, by the time you realize what you should be doing, or are pre-empting your inevitable and impending demise, it throws a curve ball and you die, having not had high enough stats.****No voice acting: Not really a con, but I would have loved some voice-action through Elodie, at least. Maybe that's just me. PROS:1) Visually appealing: Very nice art style. Simple, clean, and very polished.2) Interactivity: Highly interactive, without taking itself too seriously.3) Difficulty: It's not easy, and that's great. It doesn't hold your hand, and it makes you take responsibility for your choices, and actions, from start to finish. Elodie's innocence and ignorance are in your hands.4) Replayability: Endless.5) It's got everything: Medieval themes, magic, anime, intrigue, trade, relationships, etc.FINAL THOUGHTS:Do I recommend?What do you think?Hell yes! :DLONG LIVE THE QUEEN!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I bought and played Long Live the Queen before it was released on Steam, but decided to pick it up again for the extra content.The first and most obvious comparison most make is to Princess Maker, and I think an apt way to describe this game is Princess Maker meets Game of Thrones. However, beyond the art and the stat raising, Long Live the Queen and Princess Maker 2 don't really have that much in common. Both involve some level of strategy, but Long Live the Queen eschews the more exploratory bits for a more visual novel style. This is a game about courtly intrigue and trying to survive, and you will probably die multiple times before finally reaching your coronation day. I've heard complaints that there's little replay value, and while the game is short, it's impossible to get all the skill checks in one go, and getting certain skill checks can open up whole storylines or reveal bits of the plot that you wouldn't see if you hadn't chosen to raise that stat. If you're the type of person who needs to get everything "perfect" in one go, you will probably hate this game.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Long Live the Queen manages to resurrect the old and partially dead genre of Life Simulation/Life Management that only still lives on in the Persona series, and "graphic novels" (read as H games, because let's face it, that's all they are.) and makes it relevant again, if only slightly.Taking queues from Atlus' old Princess Maker Series from back on the Sega Saturn, Long Live the Queen manages to cut some of the old tedium the Princess Maker series had, and sheds it in favor of streamlined (albeit short) gameplay. Humorous situations are also abundant in this game, along with the innuendo here and there (what do you expect, you're the little girl).Though the soundtrack may be repetitive and grating to some, it fits the mood when the need arises and the setting is VERY European/Western, as far as the high fantasy setting goes. Character design is Animu out the wazoo, but it gets the job done while leaving opportunities for very fun still images of your princess and her various emotions.At its core, the game is really a stat management game, but the various branching paths make for a game that has much replay value, if only to see how many different ways you can die, or how far you can get. I've found myself replaying it just to see how events unfold differently with many surprises along the way. One adventure, I'm being ambushed on my way to a birthday party and died from an arrow, and another seperate playthrough I found myself having supreme military might, only to be invaded by a foreign country who decimated my forces with magic (which I was not trained in). You really never know what's going to happen outside of the first few scripted events.All in all, Long Live the Queen is a very solid game and a much recommended buy if you're in the mood to play something that will make you laugh, or make you shout "no" at the top of your lungs because you were stabbed by an assassin.

Most are for titles and money. Also, so far I've only found there to be 1 happy ending out of the many depressing ones. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Okay, you may be thinking that this game is girly, childish or whatever in the negative sense. However, the truth is that Long Live The Queen offers an incredibly fresh gaming experience. Part visual novel, part choose your own adventure, part rpg and part tamgotchi, though the sum is greater than the parts.You guide princess Elody from the time her mother's death forces her to leave boarding school up to the moment she's crowned. If you get there that is. In spite of the cheerful graphics and beautiful music this game has a brutal difficulty. You make the wrong choice? -> you die, you haven't got several skills up to snuff? -> one dead princess, you kill off a troublesome noble? -> her son runs Elody through.Every choice you make has consequences and the sheer gigantic amount of things that could (and probably will) go wrong is staggering. Yet as daunting as it makes the task, it's damn fun to try it. Additional fun comes in the form of the death scenes which (though presented in a cute way) are reminiscent of those found in Shadowgate.So, what are you still reading for? Get the game!

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Long Live The Queen (LLTQ) is a game I stumbled upon by complete accident. Let me tell you, that was one of the happiest accidents of my life.LLTQ is an anime-esque visual novel-esque...thing developed by UK based Hanako Games, and it's quite something. LLTQ is a game where you die. And die. And die again. And then you die some more. Yet, dying is part of the fun. For example: someone wrote a silly letter to you about you doing *something* with a squid. Oh, no! A gust of wind picked it up and it's now hanging just off the balcony. Do you climb out to try to grab it?>YesNoYou do? Well then, while climbing, you slip, fall, and break your neck on the ground. Your room is on the top floor of the castle, after all. Why would you try to climb from so high up? Idiot.Except maybe if you picked yes and you actually trained beforehand to be a really good climber, you didn't fall and survived. See, that's what this game is about. Each week, you pick skills to take classes in. And, every so often, you're tested in certain skills depending on what situation arises in your kingdom which could mean life or death for you. And it's oh-so-fun. True, it's very trial-and-error, but with a game like this, with muliptle paths to victory (and many more to gruesome and painful death), that's just part of the experience.This game is recommended for anyone who wants to become a pretty pink magical girl. ...I mean Lumen. (Same thing.) (Hey, it's a thing to do.)

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Not for everyone but if you are a "video games hipster" (their words not mine) like me then you will find this very amusing. It is essentially a remake of an old game called Princess Maker. A wierd blend of management sim and interactive story. You are effectively "managing" a princess to become the best ruler of the realm she will inherit. It is well designed for multiple playthroughs with various narrative paths to follow and secrets to uncover, with a bit of a roguelike approach to difficulty. The price may be a little high for some, especially if you are not sure if this is your cup of tea. If so, I highly recomment picking it up when it is on offer. If you are hankering for something completely different from the mainstream AAA selection, this could be the refreshing change of pace you have been looking for.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												If you are looking for an action-y, fast pace, adventure; turn the other way. However, if you are looking for a game with endless hours of replayability, some absolutly hilarious dialouge, a visual novel-esque story, and micromanaging, then you have come to the right place!I would honestly rate this game as one of the best I've ever played. You play as Elodie, a princess who is not yet old enough for the crown, but needs to prepare for when she is old enough. You must micromanage all of her skills in order to bring her to survive all of the horrors of being in charge.It may seem a bit overwhelming at first, failing checks left and right. But, that is the fun of it, if you die early, you know what you must prepare for in the next playthrough. Do not fret though, as you get each skill up to a higher level, you gain special outfits in order to help boost certain fields in order to let you focus on others that you may have neglected.The game is witty, fun, challenging, and always pulls you in for more.tl;dr: 10/10 would buy three times over

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												Don't go in expecting Princess Maker. Let's get this out the way first. They are similar, but the differences are vast. Skills in PM would decide the life your daughter led and what path she chose when she left the nest. Skills here decide whether you can make it to the next branch or not.It's a solid game, but you're definitely going to have to keep plenty of saves handy and a notepad, digital or otherwise, nearby.And yes, you CAN finish the game without magic... but you have to never give yourself the option of magic in the first place. Or level one specific skill you probably wouldn't expect.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												This is basically a choose your own adventure with a basic skills system attached to it. The concept is deceivingly simply, but the game itself is devilishly complicated. What impressed me the most is that even you quite frequently have to replay the same parts over and over (you can save games, but I found that quite often I would have to replay from the beginning in order to correct some minor error I had made), the game doesn't really become boring. The creative ways that they have you repeatedly die keeps it fun and interesting rather than (overly) frustrating.I found that the biggest challenge I had with this game was letting the completionist in me go. I spent the first couple of hours constantly restarting the game as I watched skill check failures scroll across the screen. Letting go of the need to pass all of those checks, and focus only on what was important to completing the story forced me to step outside my normal gaming mentality.Long Live The Queen manages to create a sense of time pressure despite being a turn based game. In that regard, it reminded me of FTL: Faster Than Light's ability make you feel that every decision is critically important because you don't have the time to fix a mistake.A significant part of the sense of pressure is the quality of the writing. Despite what could have been childish and overly campy, the story is surprisingly complex and I found myself connecting to this little anime princess and caring what happened to her.Also like FTL, I find that I wish there was a free play mode with this game that allowed you to continue the story, building skills and encountering more random events after the initial story line.  I'd even happily take another well scripted year in the life of our new Queen as she deals with her kingdom.Over all, this game is well worth the price if you are looking for a break from your usual gaming experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Misconceptions:  First off, Long Live the Queen is NOT a Medieval Dating system.  While you may have the rare opportunity to marry for political reasons, the resulting rammifications of such an action is the key point.  No drawn out romance here.  This is a game driven by politics with a focus on the feelings of our protganist, as she is thrust into unfamilar territory.Summary:  LLTQ takes you through 40 weeks of young Princess Elodie's life with the ultimate goal of...survival.  You see, Elodie has a penchant for dying.  Make the right skill checks at the right time and she'll make it through.  In a rough situation, you might even survive by making only one of several skill checks.  Just remember.  Being the perfect military strategist won't save you from being stabbed in the face, and even for a princess, climbing just might be a useful talent.Ultmately, Elodie is yours to shape.  You can train two skills each week with four "mood" sliders which dictate any bonuses (or penalties) her training will provide.  If her mood is currently "willful," she'll have an easy time with military training...but any skill under Royal Demeanor will take heavy penalities.  There can be many sides to Elodie.  Experiment and see which mood(s) will bring about the greatest skill bonuses.  I would say skill bonuses in training are tantamount to building a well-rounded princess.Cons:-This is "scripted" to a degree.  For most events, if it happens in Week 9 once...it happens in Week 9 every time.-There will be a little trial and error.  Expect to hit an event in which you've trained none of the requisite skills to survive.Pros:-A "scripted" event can play out very differently each time, depending on skills trained or the choice picked.-Variety.  Elodie can end up as a crazed Totalitarian or a champion of the people, and everything in between.-Death and avoiding it.  Dying is fun sometimes.  Other times, three or four *seemingly* random skills might each have a chance to keep you breathing.-Multiple playthroughs.  I've beaten this perhaps five times.  I feel as if there's plenty more to learn of the world.-Character.  There's something unique about LLTQ.  Pleasantly devious with a slight cute edge.  Sure, that sums it up.Final Thoughts:  Honestly, my brain is a bit foggy as I haven't played Long Live the Queen in maybe two weeks.  I don't feel as if I've given the title all the praise it deserves, nor do I currently have the words to do so.If you like Simulation-lite games, buy this.  If you like more strategy in your Simulations, buy this and aim for the tougher challenges and endings.  If you prefer RPGs...well, just buy it already.  (8.5/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Here is a story about a young princess on her road to be queen. Along the way you'll carefully teach her to become a truly regal benevolent queen... and then promptly watch her die by accident, stupidity, assassination, explosion, or gruesome murder in front of a crowd of cheering onlookers.Scratch whatever I started with.Here is a story about a naive young girl thrust into a world of cutthroat politics, scheming nobles, and capricious acquaintances. Teach her to trust no one, suspect everything, and approach all situations with borderline paranoia as she manages to cram just enough information into her tiny teenage brain to survive her final year of adolescence.Make no mistake. You will die. The world does not care that you are a cutesy 14 year old princess dressed in pink and pretty outfits.I recommend playing through without saves (saves ruin the thrill of survival). A successful playthrough will take about an hour or so once you've played a few times so death doesn't set you back all that much. As fair warning, it might take 4-5+ playthroughs just to figure out a way to beat the game utilizing your desired approach, only to realize that there are multiple approaches that require the same amount of care and "learning" (and by learning, I mean dying) as your first. This isn't a deterrent; however, as it adds addictive replayability when you ask yourself "I wonder if I could survive with 'X' type build or what would happen if I ensured that 'Y' situation ended differently."If you like mashing buttons and melting faces with combos then this game is not for you. If you have OCD and like to track stat bonuses and every piece of random information coming your way just so that you can click the correct word bubble then this is a game for you.Yep, it may look like your typical anime style visual novel but it's not. Really it's just a game comprised of pleasent music, cutesy art, and prompt death scenes. I give it a 7/10. Not the most amazing game I've ever played but addictive and affordable.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Great game!   However, if you were like me and wanted to play to see the romance, you're gonna be let-down. There is close calls, and forced (not arranged) marriges. Most are for titles and money. Also, so far I've only found there to be 1 happy ending out of the many depressing ones. Strangly, there hasn't been much talk about how her father puts everything on her, and tells her to take care of it, while he sits on throne after a few week into the game. The game can cause frusteration, since there are many impossible things to achieve.  Now for the good sides. It's not perverted in the slightest. The music, gameplay, abilities, are all spectacular. There are many routes and possiblites. It's girly on the outside, but if you ignore the child-like art and pink, it's a pretty gruesome game. It can be gory in words more than image. If you're planning on becoming queen one day, this is the game for you. You really have to think about your next more for it to all sync together.     I really did love this game...until I threw my computer out the window.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Okay, you may be thinking that this game is girly, childish or whatever in the negative sense. However, the truth is that Long Live The Queen offers an incredibly fresh gaming experience. Part visual novel, part choose your own adventure, part rpg and part tamgotchi, though the sum is greater than the parts.You guide princess Elody from the time her mother's death forces her to leave boarding school up to the moment she's crowned. If you get there that is. In spite of the cheerful graphics and beautiful music this game has a brutal difficulty. You make the wrong choice? -> you die, you haven't got several skills up to snuff? -> one dead princess, you kill off a troublesome noble? -> her son runs Elody through.Every choice you make has consequences and the sheer gigantic amount of things that could (and probably will) go wrong is staggering. Yet as daunting as it makes the task, it's damn fun to try it. Additional fun comes in the form of the death scenes which (though presented in a cute way) are reminiscent of those found in Shadowgate.So, what are you still reading for? Get the game!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												If a choose-your-own-adventure style game sounds good to you, and you don't mind getting screwed over because you don't have a skill you had zero reason to take, you could give this a shot. There's a lot of different events to see, paths to go down, etc, but it can be hard to tell how to get at certain events, some of which are determined by pretty arbitrary circumstances. Still, it's a fun setting with some pretty dark undertones (or overtones, depending on how awful you are) and has some replay value as you try to find different ways to not die horribly, and/or unlock the mysteries of the kingdom.If the trailer makes it seem appealing to you, that's exactly what you get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This is a fun game wherein you marry 14-year-old girls to old men so they don't kill you. Wait, no: it's a game where you sacrifice bouncy-haired teens to sea monsters so they don't kill the world. Hang on, no: it's a game where happy boarding school BFFs are pressured into war by dominant neighboring political parties and forced to kill each others' family. It's cute and full of anime dressup magical girl nonsense. It presents a fantastic difficulty cliff upon first loading, but the kind where you don't know you killed yourself until twenty minutes later. And when you do manage to stumble over victory, there really isn't a lot of incentive to noodle around with it any more.These are all reasons not to recommend this game. That is not what I am doing, because damn it, I watched Sailor Moon as a kid, and played Princess Maker, and had Barbies, and wanted to grow up to be a fairy supermodel rockstar princess. This kind of make-believe, aged gently so as to avoid being insufferably simple, is embarrassingly welcome.Wonder if I'm too old for princess camp...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												This is basically a choose your own adventure with a basic skills system attached to it. The concept is deceivingly simply, but the game itself is devilishly complicated. What impressed me the most is that even you quite frequently have to replay the same parts over and over (you can save games, but I found that quite often I would have to replay from the beginning in order to correct some minor error I had made), the game doesn't really become boring. The creative ways that they have you repeatedly die keeps it fun and interesting rather than (overly) frustrating.I found that the biggest challenge I had with this game was letting the completionist in me go. I spent the first couple of hours constantly restarting the game as I watched skill check failures scroll across the screen. Letting go of the need to pass all of those checks, and focus only on what was important to completing the story forced me to step outside my normal gaming mentality.Long Live The Queen manages to create a sense of time pressure despite being a turn based game. In that regard, it reminded me of FTL: Faster Than Light's ability make you feel that every decision is critically important because you don't have the time to fix a mistake.A significant part of the sense of pressure is the quality of the writing. Despite what could have been childish and overly campy, the story is surprisingly complex and I found myself connecting to this little anime princess and caring what happened to her.Also like FTL, I find that I wish there was a free play mode with this game that allowed you to continue the story, building skills and encountering more random events after the initial story line.  I'd even happily take another well scripted year in the life of our new Queen as she deals with her kingdom.Over all, this game is well worth the price if you are looking for a break from your usual gaming experience.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This game is like my new addiction.  I asked some friends who owned the game what it was about, and they all recommended it.  Therefore, I tried it out.  During my first play-through, I was a little disappointed.....but then I got addicted after dying the first time.  Your first few play-throughs will be dedicated to beating the game (which you will most likely not do your first few play times).  After you beat the game, then comes the real challenge: finding all the deaths and achievements.  Yes, this is a game where the ending is boring, and the stuff in-between is what you want.This game is both entertaining and frustrating.  Every choice you make influences the gameplay, and I'm amazed by how many possibilities there are.  I know I still haven't found them all.  As you play more of the game, you learn what choices can help or hurt you, but it's the things you never think of that may get you achievements.  Some of the achievements are super easy, but others are super hard to achieve.  You can have the princess all set-up to do well on one scenario, but find out later that a choice you made earlier in the game caused you to completely skip that scenario.  It keeps the game interesting, and it will get you hooked.What are the downsides to this game?  Well, it can get very, very repetitive.  You can skip certain dialogues, but that only speeds things up a little.  When you are trying to get to a scenario in week 35, it takes forever to get to that point because you have to play through each week.  Yes, you can save right before that scenario and go back to it in case something goes wrong, but you want to make sure you have the correct classes and mood.  That can take a while to build-up when you start at the beginning of the game.  The save files help sometimes, but you may end up with so many saved games that you forget what is what even if you name them.  There are sooo many pieces to the game that need to be right that it's not really worth saving a game all the time.Is it worth the $10?  To me, I think it's worth a little less.  I really wanted this game, so I waited until it was on sale half off.  It was worth that price, but I do think the full price is a little much.  If they expanded on the game, it may be.  It's one of those games that's fun to play at first, but once you figure everything out, the game will lose most of the fun aspect.  However, I can guarantee it will take a ton of gameplay to earn all acheivements if you aren't cheating.  35 hours of gameplay later, and I still have 1 death, 2 epilogues, and 4 acheivements to find.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This is a pretty short VN/stat management type game with a lot of replayability. Your job is to knock a whiny little loli girl into shape so that she can face the rigours of being the Queen of some magical fantasy country. As the story goes on, people will try to poison and stab you and so you have to train your little ♥♥♥♥♥ to handle the situation. Like if you don't train your girl in manners and composure or whatever, she'll get sent poison chocolates and IMMEDIATELY EAT THEM, which is maybe not great. There's a bit of trial and error involved. I mean, you would never really think the 'Decoration' skill would be useful but it ends up being of potentially critical importance in a magic duel. But both reloading and restarting are fast enough that no sudden deaths are particularly bothersome.Eventually, I made my girl into a ninja magic lady, who defeated the evil wizard and went on to found the FIGHT SCHOOL. I'll probably play it a few more times to see what else might happen.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Long Live the Queen is a game of experimentation at the hands of skill checks thoughout the story. You need to balance the emotional state of your Princess in order to gain the most bonuses needed to survive the endless masses trying to remove you from power. The deaths are tasteful artworks and the uniforms are well designed. The game has a simple tutorial which can be easily bypassed once you know what you are doing. Be prepared to start the game repeatedly as you gain knowledge in what you need to prepare for. There are multiple ways in getting past each encounter but the key is making sure you don't run out of time and fall prey to an event you forgot about! It is a game of muscle memory and worth the time invested if you like skill management. There is a humorous take to the game many would enjoy as they trigger various hidden events and new ways to meet your demise!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												The general impression I got from everyone when they saw me playing this game was “ew why are you playing a game so girly”. But once you look past it, this game is really strong in all aspects. It tells a great story, allows you to play how you want to play and the music is really strong. It is a good gateway for an experience in being a royal member, or just an important figure. What you do is important for your people and you. The choices you make and the lessons you take can turn your road to coronation to a sadly short life. Each death you have you looking at what you did wrong and how you faltered in your classes. The real strategy of this game comes from taking advantage of your moods to get the most out of your lessons. The reward of surviving so much is very satisfying and it makes all of the deaths from chocolate and bandits on my way to a birthday party worth it. I have no regrets getting this game, and it would be there up there as one of my favourite games.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Long Live The Queen plays a lot like a dating sim, without the dating, and an interactive visual novel (like Hate an analogue story and Katawa Shoujo), putting you in the shoes of a young princess facing a hostile world that is out to kill her after the loss of her mother. Challenging, quirky, playful and surprisingly deep, LLTQ loves to give you a myriad of decisions, and makes you face the consequences afterwards. If you enjoy VNs, this may just be the game for you; but be warned, the only action you'll see is in the text.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												It's a hard world out there. It's even harder when your mother has an untimely death and you are thrust into the throne at only 14.LLTQ is another one of those RenPy, visual-novelesque story-based games - a genre that I very much enjoy after playing pretty much all of Christine Love's games (don't take it personally, Analogue, Digital, Hate Plus).As you would expect from a visual-novel type game, there are multiple endings: some of which I haven't reached yet, but the ones I have were very entertaining and kept me hooked for a good while.There's quite a lot of depth in this game in the wide variety of choices you can make, from the normal event choices you usually come across in a VN to making the choice of which skill you are going to improve. The game constantly punishes and rewards you for these choices: not only may the wrong choice affect your in-game mood, but your reputation across the kingdom as well. Elodie can die in 9 ways (I think), and each playthrough will reward you with pretty much a different one every time. In terms of variety - as long as you alter your playstyle - this game has much to offer. For the price it was on the Winter Sale, it was an absolute steal; but now it's over, I would wait to see the price drop in the next big sale before grabbing it. If you're on the fence about buying the game, go play Don't Take It Personally Babe, It Just Ain't Your Story (it's free to download at scoutshonour.com) to see whether that style of game is something you'd like. You never know, it might just be.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												In Long Live The Queen you play as Princes Elodie, the incoming Queen. It is up to you to ensure that the Princess lives to be crowned Queen.The game works on a weekly cycle. At the start of every week you will be required to choose two classes in which Elodie will participate. These classes will determine which skills are increased. It is important to note the Elodie's mood, as her mood will determine the bonus or penalty to learning skills. For example, if Elodie is depressed, she will not be very fond of attending a class on court manners, hence, that skill will receive a penalty, and spending time on it will not result in any meaningful increases.On the weekend, you are given the choice of a weekend activity, which will determine changes to Elodie's mood.Interspersed are events that require Elodie's skills to be of a certain level in order to be successful, and if not, a negative outcome results. These events give life to the story, and illuminate the intrigue of Nova and its people: noble, commoners, and criminals alike.The gameplay can be rather formulaic, however, the beauty and tactical reasoning arises when determining the combinations of skills that will keep you alive, and keep your realm and people safe.The magic of the game is found in honing one's skills of forecasting and strategy. Seems like tensions in the realm are rising? Do I prepare for war or hope for the best? These are some of the questions that may need answers as you play, knowing that the wrong decision could very well prove fatal.It is a perfect Groundhog Day scenario to experiment with choices and their ramifications. Visually, it has an anime-esque appeal, but one wishes for a greater variety of scenes and backgrounds. The outfits, which are unlocked by increasing skills in the same branch, are very well designed and emphasise Elodie's demeanour and personality.I highly recommend Long Live The Queen for players interested in a strategy game with flair.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Long Live the Queen is a game of experimentation at the hands of skill checks thoughout the story. You need to balance the emotional state of your Princess in order to gain the most bonuses needed to survive the endless masses trying to remove you from power. The deaths are tasteful artworks and the uniforms are well designed. The game has a simple tutorial which can be easily bypassed once you know what you are doing. Be prepared to start the game repeatedly as you gain knowledge in what you need to prepare for. There are multiple ways in getting past each encounter but the key is making sure you don't run out of time and fall prey to an event you forgot about! It is a game of muscle memory and worth the time invested if you like skill management. There is a humorous take to the game many would enjoy as they trigger various hidden events and new ways to meet your demise!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												The general impression I got from everyone when they saw me playing this game was “ew why are you playing a game so girly”. But once you look past it, this game is really strong in all aspects. It tells a great story, allows you to play how you want to play and the music is really strong. It is a good gateway for an experience in being a royal member, or just an important figure. What you do is important for your people and you. The choices you make and the lessons you take can turn your road to coronation to a sadly short life. Each death you have you looking at what you did wrong and how you faltered in your classes. The real strategy of this game comes from taking advantage of your moods to get the most out of your lessons. The reward of surviving so much is very satisfying and it makes all of the deaths from chocolate and bandits on my way to a birthday party worth it. I have no regrets getting this game, and it would be there up there as one of my favourite games.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Long Live The Queen plays a lot like a dating sim, without the dating, and an interactive visual novel (like Hate an analogue story and Katawa Shoujo), putting you in the shoes of a young princess facing a hostile world that is out to kill her after the loss of her mother. Challenging, quirky, playful and surprisingly deep, LLTQ loves to give you a myriad of decisions, and makes you face the consequences afterwards. If you enjoy VNs, this may just be the game for you; but be warned, the only action you'll see is in the text.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												It looks pink, fluffy and easy but if you give it a try you will soon see that keeping your princess alive by teaching her the right skills at the right time is very demanding and tricky. Fortunately seeing all the various ways in which she can perish is half the fun because she will die. A lot.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												It's a hard world out there. It's even harder when your mother has an untimely death and you are thrust into the throne at only 14.LLTQ is another one of those RenPy, visual-novelesque story-based games - a genre that I very much enjoy after playing pretty much all of Christine Love's games (don't take it personally, Analogue, Digital, Hate Plus).As you would expect from a visual-novel type game, there are multiple endings: some of which I haven't reached yet, but the ones I have were very entertaining and kept me hooked for a good while.There's quite a lot of depth in this game in the wide variety of choices you can make, from the normal event choices you usually come across in a VN to making the choice of which skill you are going to improve. The game constantly punishes and rewards you for these choices: not only may the wrong choice affect your in-game mood, but your reputation across the kingdom as well. Elodie can die in 9 ways (I think), and each playthrough will reward you with pretty much a different one every time. In terms of variety - as long as you alter your playstyle - this game has much to offer. For the price it was on the Winter Sale, it was an absolute steal; but now it's over, I would wait to see the price drop in the next big sale before grabbing it. If you're on the fence about buying the game, go play Don't Take It Personally Babe, It Just Ain't Your Story (it's free to download at scoutshonour.com) to see whether that style of game is something you'd like. You never know, it might just be.

Seems like there's a decent amount of replayability, and I look forward to discovering the other endings (if I survive...).

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												ok, I'm really enjoying this game. There is never enough time to learn every skill you want to, and the notification system lets you know what skills caused you to fail (and possibly die). But trying and failing is half the fun with this game.It's all about trade offs and compromises. Will you ignore courtly interactions (and look foolish at the balls) to train up your spycraft, or perhaps you will ignore world history (and look foolish when it comes to border disputes) to learn all about archery (so those bandits don't make you look like a pincushion). Maybe you will learn all about battlefield medicine (so you can survive looking like a pincushion), but no longer have time for music and dance lessions.Everything has a purpose, and no skill is wasted. It's all about trying (and failing >.<) to see things coming.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This game is fantastic. I have recommended it and sent it to friends and family to play and all of them got hooked.While, superficially, it is pink and cuteness and bows - that really is all entirely on the surface. Elodie can become anything she wants at all. A cute Queen with nothing but flattery and court manners in her head, a master military strategist, a cunning master of intrigue or a simple healing girl who loves lore. Any of it, any combination of, even. There are no "best" options for what you want Elodie to be - and that is the greatest feature of this game. There is no "right" or "wrong". Just the desire to survive and reach her coronation and safety. You can unravel storylines with different choices and the multitude of choices gives very different gaming each time. Even when your mind is screaming to pick Option A because you feel it is right, you can be surprised with the outcomes of Options B, C or D.It can appeal to anyone. So much so, in fact, that I even got my partner to play it and he enjoyed it despite not really being a gamer. The only games he does play involve zombies and yet he was cackling along and loving some of the aspects of this game. He got really upset when he got shot with arrows (which I knew was going to happen and did nothing to help him circumvent it. haha.)That and trying to collect all of the deaths is really quite fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												In this game, the ultimate goal is to get Elodie(the protaganist) to become Queen. First off, the graphics and music absolutely make this game. Everything is bright and pleasant, possibly to distract you from the impending frustrations you will face trying to:1.) Improve skills2.) Accept disappointment for not improving skills fast enough3.) Not dieContrary to the title, Elodie may not live long at all based off of the decisions you make. Something as simple as attending a party, accepting gifts and eating chocolate can very well guarantee death. With this in mind, if you don't mind saving every few seconds and have enough patience, this will be a breeze. Otherwise, it will be maddening every time you attempt to play. I recommend this game to anyone that does not mind putting time and effort into a game, as this is not your standard visual novel.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Not the greatest game ever, but still a pleasant surprise.Don't be fooled by the pink interface, cheerful character and visual novel style. This is first and foremost a strategy game where you have to decide where you should allocate your few training points to avoid all the dangers waiting for you. There is nothing random in the game, everything is determined by your skill points and the skill tests against them.Unless you're a completionist that want to unlock all the achievements/endings, it should take your about 3 or 4H to finish the game. Completing everything would require either extensive note takings, or checking a wiki (don't do that before finishing the game once by yourself !), as there are a lot of stuff that is not at all obvious and require planning far in advance.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Fantastic game with cute graphic, yet much more serious story. You are playing as Elodie and your job is to plan her day, so that she learn different things (crucial stat raising aspect), which is also linked to Elodie's mood (depending on it you may get boost for learning particular skill or the opposite, it may become harder). You also make important decisions. There are a lot of moments when your statistics gets verified and very often there is more than just one way of handling the situation (and failing to do so may even result in your death). This game is addictive and challenging, there are plenty of "easy-to-fail" moments, though it also deliver a lot of different endings. It has high replay value especially if you're aiming to get all of achievements. The only con is game's length - it my opinion it should take a little longer to raise statistics and game should take place during more than just one year of ruling. But this actually prove of how good this game is - I wish I could play it longer, with more options and more story.I recommend it :)

												It's neat, but sorta frustrating. I think the visual novel concept sorta hinders the actual decision-making, primarily because there are hard skillchecks that require you to replay the game a bunch to not die. While that's intentional, I'm sure, it also kinda artificallly increases the amount of time I have to spend reading text that I've already seen a bunch of times.I think the game could really use some sort of flag system based on which skill checks you've seen/not seen that records whether or not you passed the check and what skill level you were at. While I'm a big fan of taking notes when playing adventure games, it's sorta boring to have to remember whether or not I needed 25 or 35 dancing skill to impress my dad's friends.It's a neat game, but I wouldn't actually reccomend it to anyone who doesn't already really like this genre.
